case_name: State of Assam v. Mool Chand Sarougi

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 595 of 1967 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 595 of 1967. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated July 28, 1966 of Assam and Nagaland High Court in Civil Rule No. 242 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated July 28, 1966, of the Assam and Nagaland High Court in Civil Rule No. 242 of 1964.

facts.text: Divisional Forest Officer, Kamrup Division, Assam invited tenders for purchase of monopoly rights to quarry stone from certain areas including Harengi Stone Quarry Mahal for period July 1, 1963 to June 30, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The Divisional Forest Officer, Kamrup Division, Assam invited tenders for the purchase of monopoly rights to quarry stone from certain areas, including Harengi Stone Quarry Mahal, for the period July 1, 1963 to June 30, 1964.

facts.text: Mool Chand Sarougi submitted a tender with Rs. 100 earnest money and offered Rs. 5.25 per rupee of royalty.

anchor.surface_text: Mool Chand Sarougi-hereinafter called the respondent submitted a tender accompanied by the requisite deposit of Rs. 100/- as earnest money, and offered the rate of Rs. 5.25 per rupee of royalty.

facts.text: Respondent's tender was accepted and allotted minimum quantity of 1,25,000 c.ft. of stone for which he was to pay Rs. 31,250.

anchor.surface_text: The tender, submitted by the respondent was accepted and for the minimum quantity of 1,25,000 c. ft. of stone allotted to the respondent out of the quarry he was to pay Rs. 31,250/-

facts.text: Intimation of acceptance of the tender was given to respondent on July 13, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: . Intimation of acceptance of the tender was given to the respondent on July 13, 1963.

facts.text: Baputi Ram, member of scheduled tribe, appealed against acceptance of tender to Government of Assam and obtained stay order.

anchor.surface_text: One Baputi Ram, a member of a scheduled tribe, appealed against the order of the Divisional Forest Officer accepting the, tender, to the Government of Assam and obtained a stay order.

facts.text: After about three months Baputi Ram declined to prosecute the appeal and it was dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: After about three months he declined to prosecute the appeal and his appeal was dismissed.

facts.text: Respondent declined to accept the settlement of the quarry.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then declined to, accept the settlement of the quarry.

facts.text: Divisional Forest Officer invited fresh tenders but offers were not accepted and tenders invited again.

anchor.surface_text: The Divisional Forest Officer invited fresh tenders. The offers made were number however accepted and tenders were invited again.

facts.text: On January 10, 1964 settlement made for minimum 50,000 c.ft. for period January 25, 1964 to June 30, 1964 for Rs. 10,000.

anchor.surface_text: On January 10, 1964 a settlement was made for a minimum quantity of 50,000 c. ft. for the period from January 25, 1964 to June 30, 1964 for Rs. 10,000/-

facts.text: Divisional Forest Officer sought to recover Rs. 31,250 as arrears of land revenue under S.75 Assam Forest Regulation VII of 1891.

anchor.surface_text: The Divisional Forest Officer, thereafter, sought to recover the amount of Rs. 31,250/- for which the tender of the respondent was accepted as arrears of land revenue in the manner provided by S. 75 of the Assam Forest Regulation VII of 1891.

facts.text: Respondent filed petition in High Court of Assam to quash recovery proceeding.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then moved a petition in the High Court of Assam for an order quashing the proceeding for recovery of the amount demanded.

facts.text: High Court held amount not recoverable under Assam Forest Regulation VII of 1891, quashed proceeding, issued mandamus to Divisional Forest Officer not to recover.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the amount claimed was, number recoverable under the provisions of the Assam Forest Regulation, VII of 1891 and passed an order quashing the proceeding for recovery and issued a mandamus to the Divisional Forest Officer, Kamrup Division number to proceed with the recovery.

facts.text: State of Assam appealed to Supreme Court with certificate from High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Assam has appealed to this Court with certificate granted by the High Court.

facts.text: Amount claimed is not on account of price of forest produce or expenses incurred in execution of Regulation.

anchor.surface_text: The amount claimed to be due from the respondent is number on account of the price of any forest produce, or of expenses incurred in the execution for recovery of any forest produce.

facts.text: Amount not due in execution of the Regulation, common ground.

anchor.surface_text: The amount is also number due in the execution of the Regulation. So far there is companymon ground.

facts.text: Petitioner claimed amount due under rule 10 under the Regulation, recoverable as arrears.

anchor.surface_text: It was claimed, however, that the amount was due under rule 10 promulgated in exercise of power under the Regulation and on that account it was recoverable as an arrear of land revnue.

facts.text: Baputi Ram is a member of a scheduled tribe.

anchor.surface_text: One Baputi Ram, a member of a scheduled tribe,

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Shah, C.J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shah, C.J.

facts.text: Tenders invited by Divisional Forest Officer, Kamrup Division, Assam.

anchor.surface_text: The Divisional Forest Officer, Kamrup Division, Assam invited tenders for the purchase

facts.text: Fresh settlement made for Rs. 10,000 which is less than original Rs. 31,250.

facts.text: Rule 10 provides no lease for fixed period for certain forest produce except per Conservator orders.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 10 provides No lease for any fixed period giving the right of removing India rubber, cane, kutcha or cutch, lac, agar, ivory, or any other forests produce shall be given otherwise than in accordance with the general or special orders of the Conservator...

facts.text: Court held rule 10 does not apply to recovery for failure to carry out tender obligations.

anchor.surface_text: The Rule in our judgment does number apply to recovery of the amount alleged to be due for failure to carry out the obligations ,of the tender by proceedings under the Assam Forest Regulation 1891.

Section 75 of the Assam Forest Regulation VII of 1891 provides All money, other than fines, payable to Crown under this Regulation, or under any rule made thereunder, or on account of the price of any forest produce, or of expenses incurred in the execution of this Regulation in respect of any forest produce, may, if number paid when due, be recovered under the law for the time being in force as if it were an arrear of land revenue.

concepts.interpretation: The provision allows recovery as arrears of land revenue only for moneys payable under the Regulation or rules, price of forest produce, or execution expenses related to forest produce. The claimed amount for failed tender is none of these.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: recovered under the law for the time, being in force as if it were an arrear of land revenue. The amount claimed to be due from the respondent is num

concepts.unlisted_description: Recovery of specified moneys due under the Regulation as arrears of land revenue.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 10 provides No lease for any fixed period giving the right of removing India rubber, cane, kutcha or cutch, lac, agar, ivory, or any other forests produce shall be given otherwise than in accordance with the general or special orders of the Conservator who is empowered to authorise sales in respect of such leases, by auction, tender or any other method at such rates as he may decide in his discretion.

concepts.interpretation: Rule regulates procedure for granting leases of certain forest produce; does not create monetary liability or authorize recovery of tender shortfalls via Regulation.

issues.text: Whether the amount of Rs. 31,250/- claimed from the respondent is recoverable as arrears of land revenue under Section 75 of the Assam Forest Regulation, 1891

anchor.surface_text: sought to recover the amount of Rs. 31,250/- for which the tender of the respondent was accepted as arrears of land revenue in the manner provided by S. 75 of the Assam Forest Regulation VII of 1891. The respondent then moved a petition in the High Court of Assam for an order quashing the proceeding for recovery of the amount demanded. The High Court held that the amount claimed was, number recoverable under the provisions of the Assam Forest Regulation, VII of 1891 and passed an order quashing the proceeding for recovery and issued a mandamus to the Divisional Forest Officer, Kamrup Division number to proceed with the recovery.

issues.text: Whether the claimed amount is money payable under the Assam Forest Regulation or any rule made thereunder, specifically on account of the price of forest produce or expenses incurred in execution of the Regulation

anchor.surface_text: Section 75 of the Assam Forest Regulation VII of 1891 provides All money, other than fines, payable to Crown under this Regulation, or under any rule made thereunder, or on account of the price of any forest produce, or of expenses incurred in the execution of this Regulation in respect of any forest produce, may, if number paid when due, be recovered under the law for the time being in force as if it were an arrear of land revenue. The amount claimed to be due from the respondent is number on account of the price of any forest produce, or of expenses incurred in the execution for recovery of any forest produce. The amount is also number due in the execution of the Regulation. So far there is companymon ground.

issues.text: Whether the amount is due under Rule 10 promulgated under the Assam Forest Regulation and thus recoverable under Section 75

anchor.surface_text: It was claimed, however, that the amount was due under rule 10 promulgated in exercise of power under the Regulation and on that account it was recoverable as an arrear of land revnue. Rule 10 provides No lease for any fixed period giving the right of removing India rubber, cane, kutcha or cutch, lac, agar, ivory, or any other forests produce shall be given otherwise than in accordance with the general or special orders of the Conservator who is empowered to authorise sales in respect of such leases, by auction, tender or any other method at such rates as he may decide in his discretion.

arguments.claim: The Rule does not give rise to any liability to pay a sum of money; it merely imposes a limitation upon the power of the officers to grant leases

anchor.surface_text: In any event the Rule does number give rise to any liability to pay a sum of money. It merely imposes a limitation upon the power of the officers of the Forest Department to grant leases in respect of certain forest produce. Ile lease may number be granted except in accordance with the general or special orders of the Conservator who alone As empowered to authorise a sale in respect of such a lease. It is a rule relating to the exercise of power to grant leases.
